column1: TaliskaThe name "Taliska" is used in this article conventionally. See #Other versions of the Legendarium was a Mannish language spoken by the Edain of the House of Bëor and House of Hador.
==Origins==

The ancestors of the folk of Beor and Marach were originally one group when they migrated to the West. In the northern Rhûn they met some Dwarves who probably influenced their language. It was at the Northern shore of the Sea of Rhûn that the tribes separated. They didnt meet often
The House of Hador seemed to have been related to the ancestors of the Northmen
column2: note 4 (whose language eventually evolved in the various Northern Mannish in the Third Age). The House of Bëor had extensive contact with the Dark Elves
column3: they adopted "many words and devices" that influenced their language.

column1: ==Other versions of the Legendarium==
Helge Fauskanger and Ellen Schousboe noted several changes in the conception of Taliska:
*The name "Taliska" originally referred to the language of the Houses of Bëor and Haleth whereas it was the House of Hador that spoke another language
column2: which would eventually be conceived as Adûnaic. In an early text by Tolkien
column3: some words he labels as Taliska refer to terms which in the later version would be used by the Haladin.

column1: *Later
column2: in the essay "Of Dwarves and Men" (published in The Peoples of Middle-Earth)
column3: Tolkien wrote that the Bëorians and Halethians did not speak related languages: The Hadorians still spoke "ancient Adûnaic"
column4: and the Bëorians had a closely related language; it was the language of Halethians that was unrelated to both of them (see pre-Númenorean).

column1: The later conception establishes a wider Hadorian/Beorian language
column2: which however is not given a name. The fate of the term Taliska is vague
column3: and while it could refer to the Halethian isolate (cf. the older conception) sometimes its used conventionally to refer to the Hadorian/Beorian family.

column1: ==Inspiration==
Taliska was an early language developed by Tolkien. Unlike his later languages which are Wikipedia:A_priori_(languages)
column2: it was based directly on the Germanic languages
column3: and has a lot in common with the Gothic language
column5: p. 22 this shows that Tolkien tried to connect his mythos with the origins of Europe
column6: something that was evident in the The Book of Lost Tales.

column1: The connection with Germanic persisted in the framework of The Lord of the Rings. The Mannish languages that would derive from Adunaic
column5: modern English etc. Non-Taliskan languages are usually rendered with Celtic elements
column6: if at all. (q.v. for more references).
